elements.content: Diphenylbismuth ethoxide, Ph2BiOEt, initiates the ring-opening polymerization of ε-caprolactone via a coordination-insertion mechanism. The matrix assisted laser induced desorption and ionization-time-of-flight (MALDI−TOF) mass spectra proved the formation of one ethyl ester and one CH2OH endgroup. The reactivity of this initiator is high enough to allow even for polymerizations at 20 °C. At 120 °C the reactivity of Ph2BiOEt is lower than that of tin(II) 2-ethylhexanoate (SnOct2) + ethanol, whereas below 90 °C, the reactivity of Ph2BiOEt is higher. Small amounts of cyclic oligoesters are even formed at 20 °C. At 120 °C the number average molecular weights (M ns) parallel the monomer-initiator ratios, and Mns up to 115 000 Da were obtained. The time−conversion curves and the crystal structure indicate association of Ph2BiOEt via O → Bi donor–acceptor interactions.
elements.clean_text: Diphenylbismuth ethoxide, Ph2BiOEt, initiates the ring-opening polymerization of ε-caprolactone via a coordination-insertion mechanism. The matrix assisted laser induced desorption and ionization-time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF) mass spectra proved the formation of one ethyl ester and one CH2OH endgroup. The reactivity of this initiator is high enough to allow even for polymerizations at 20 °C. At 120 °C the reactivity of Ph2BiOEt is lower than that of tin(II) 2-ethylhexanoate (SnOct2) + ethanol, whereas below 90 °C, the reactivity of Ph2BiOEt is higher. Small amounts of cyclic oligoesters are even formed at 20 °C. At 120 °C the number average molecular weights (M ns) parallel the monomer-initiator ratios, and Mns up to 115000 Da were obtained. The time-conversion curves and the crystal structure indicate association of Ph2BiOEt via O → Bi donor-acceptor interactions.

elements.content: For both academic research and technical production of biodegradable polyesters tin compounds and, in particular, tin(II) 2-ethylhexanoate (SnOct2) play a predominant role as initiators or catalysts. Yet, tin compounds are cytotoxic, which means they are toxic to almost all animals, microbes, and fungi. Therefore, it is predictable that on the long-term tin compounds need to be replaced by less toxic initiators/catalysts. A first step in this direction is the banning of tributyl tin derivatives from marine paints since 2003, where they were long used as efficient antifouling agents.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

For both academic research and technical production of biodegradable polyesters tin compounds and, in particular, tin(II) 2-ethylhexanoate (SnOct2) play a predominant role as initiators or catalysts. Yet, tin compounds are cytotoxic, which means they are toxic to almost all animals, microbes, and fungi. Therefore, it is predictable that on the long-term tin compounds need to be replaced by less toxic initiators/catalysts. A first step in this direction is the banning of tributyl tin derivatives from marine paints since 2003, where they were long used as efficient antifouling agents.

elements.content: In the field of biodegradable polyesters, several research groups have began to evaluate the usefulness of magnesium, calcium, zinc, and iron salts or complexes as nontoxic initiators or catalysts. Calcium and magnesium salts or complexes may possess an extremely low toxicity and high reactivity, but they are so basic that they racemize l-lactide at the temperatures needed for technical polymerizations. Particularly reactive calcium and magnesium compounds such as Bu2Mg racemize l-lactide even at 20–25 °C. Zinc salts and compounds are far less toxic than tin derivatives, but are also less reactive, and most zinc salts also racemize l-lactide at temperatures >100 °C. None the less, initiators or catalysts based on zinc seem to be the best compromise. Recently, zirconium acetyl acetonate and alkoxides were also considered, because zirconium compounds seem to be less toxic than tin compounds. Yet, zirconium is more toxic than zinc and is not significantly more reactive as initiator.
elements.clean_text: In the field of biodegradable polyesters, several research groups have began to evaluate the usefulness of magnesium, calcium, zinc, and iron salts or complexes as nontoxic initiators or catalysts. Calcium and magnesium salts or complexes may possess an extremely low toxicity and high reactivity, but they are so basic that they racemize l-lactide at the temperatures needed for technical polymerizations. Particularly reactive calcium and magnesium compounds such as Bu2Mg racemize l-lactide even at 20-25 °C. Zinc salts and compounds are far less toxic than tin derivatives, but are also less reactive, and most zinc salts also racemize l-lactide at temperatures >100 °C. None the less, initiators or catalysts based on zinc seem to be the best compromise. Recently, zirconium acetyl acetonate and alkoxides were also considered, because zirconium compounds seem to be less toxic than tin compounds. Yet, zirconium is more toxic than zinc and is not significantly more reactive as initiator.

elements.content: About 5 years ago, the first author of this work launched a research program concerning the usefulness of bismuth compounds as initiators or catalysts in the field of biodegradable and biocompatible polymers. Bismuth oxides and carboxylates (e.g., “subcitrate” or “subsalicylate”) have a tradition of more than 100 years as an internal drug against gastrointestinal complaints (including stomach ulcer). Furthermore, they have a long tradition as external drugs, namely as compounds of ointments designed for skin care and treatment of burn wounds (Xeroform, Noviform, and Dermatol in Europe, for example). Furthermore, it was recently found that bismuth nitrate is less toxic for kidney tubuli than other heavy metals including zinc ions. Hence, bismuth may be the least toxic heavy metal and from this point of view an interesting candidate for substitution of tin, lead, or mercury salts in various reactions. Several publications recently demonstrated that bismuth salts catalyze homopolymerizations of ε-caprolactone and l-lactide and copolymerizations of these monomers with each other or with glycolide and trimethylene carbonate. A variety of telechelic polymers and other architectures were prepared. However, it is difficult to prepare high molar mass polyesters having number average molecular weights (M ns) > 40 000 Da. The purpose of this study is to present the first results obtained with a single-site Bi-initiator having a bismuth alkoxide group. Since metal alkoxides are usually the most reactive type of initiators, it was intended to elucidate, if Ph2BiOEt allows for the preparation of high molar mass polylactones together with a control of M n via the monomer−initiator (M/I) ratio. Furthermore, its reactivity as initiator should be compared with that of SnOct2.
elements.clean_text: About 5 years ago, the first author of this work launched a research program concerning the usefulness of bismuth compounds as initiators or catalysts in the field of biodegradable and biocompatible polymers. Bismuth oxides and carboxylates (e.g., "subcitrate" or "subsalicylate") have a tradition of more than 100 years as an internal drug against gastrointestinal complaints (including stomach ulcer). Furthermore, they have a long tradition as external drugs, namely as compounds of ointments designed for skin care and treatment of burn wounds (Xeroform, Noviform, and Dermatol in Europe, for example). Furthermore, it was recently found that bismuth nitrate is less toxic for kidney tubuli than other heavy metals including zinc ions. Hence, bismuth may be the least toxic heavy metal and from this point of view an interesting candidate for substitution of tin, lead, or mercury salts in various reactions. Several publications recently demonstrated that bismuth salts catalyze homopolymerizations of ε-caprolactone and l-lactide and copolymerizations of these monomers with each other or with glycolide and trimethylene carbonate. A variety of telechelic polymers and other architectures were prepared. However, it is difficult to prepare high molar mass polyesters having number average molecular weights (M ns) > 40000 Da. The purpose of this study is to present the first results obtained with a single-site Bi-initiator having a bismuth alkoxide group. Since metal alkoxides are usually the most reactive type of initiators, it was intended to elucidate, if Ph2BiOEt allows for the preparation of high molar mass polylactones together with a control of M n via the monomer-initiator (M/I) ratio. Furthermore, its reactivity as initiator should be compared with that of SnOct2.

elements.content: ε-Caprolactone (εCL, purity 99%) was purchased from ACROS Organics (Geel, Belgium) and distilled in vacuo over powdered calcium hydride (called “dry”). Alternatively, it was distilled over P4O10 in vacuo (with a loss around 50%) after distillation over freshly powdered CaH2 (called “ultra dry”). Tetra(ethylene glycol), TEG (purity 99.5%), purchased from ACROS was azeotropically dried with toluene and distilled in a vacuum of 10−2 mbar. Tin(II) 2-ethylhexanoate (SnOct2, purity 95%) was purchased from Aldrich Co. (Milwaukee, WI) and purified as described previously. Bismuth(III) n-hexanoate was prepared from bismuth(III) acetate as described previously. Phenyl magnesium chloride (2.0 M in tetrahydrofuran), bismuth trichloride (purity >98%), and bismuth tribromide (purity >98%) were all purchased from Aldrich Co. and used as received. Toluene, diethyl ether, and tetrahydrofuran (THF) were refluxed and distilled over sodium wire. Dichloromethane were distilled over P4O10. Diphenyl bismuth ethoxide (Ph2BiOEt) was prepared according to a published procedure, but potassium tert-butoxide (purity >95%) was used instead of sodium methoxide (mp 143–146 °C dec, in agreement with the litaterature data).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

ε-Caprolactone (εCL, purity 99%) was purchased from ACROS Organics (Geel, Belgium) and distilled in vacuo over powdered calcium hydride (called "dry"). Alternatively, it was distilled over P4O10 in vacuo (with a loss around 50%) after distillation over freshly powdered CaH2 (called "ultra dry"). Tetra(ethylene glycol), TEG (purity 99.5%), purchased from ACROS was azeotropically dried with toluene and distilled in a vacuum of 10-2 mbar. Tin(II) 2-ethylhexanoate (SnOct2, purity 95%) was purchased from Aldrich Co. (Milwaukee, WI) and purified as described previously. Bismuth(III) n-hexanoate was prepared from bismuth(III) acetate as described previously. Phenyl magnesium chloride (2.0 M in tetrahydrofuran), bismuth trichloride (purity >98%), and bismuth tribromide (purity >98%) were all purchased from Aldrich Co. and used as received. Toluene, diethyl ether, and tetrahydrofuran (THF) were refluxed and distilled over sodium wire. Dichloromethane were distilled over P4O10. Diphenyl bismuth ethoxide (Ph2BiOEt) was prepared according to a published procedure, but potassium tert-butoxide (purity >95%) was used instead of sodium methoxide (mp 143-146 °C dec, in agreement with the litaterature data).

elements.content: ε-Caprolactone (50 mmol) and Ph2BiOEt (0.5 mmol) were weighed under nitrogen into a 25 mL Erlenmeyer flask having silanized glass walls. The reaction vessel was closed with glass-stopper and steel spring and immersed into an oil bath preheated to 120 °C. After 0.5 h at 120 °C and cooling the polylactone was dissolved in dichloromethane and precipitated into cold diethyl ether.
elements.clean_text:
Polymerizations

(A) With Dry ε-Caprolactone (No. 2, Table ).

ε-Caprolactone (50 mmol) and Ph2BiOEt (0.5 mmol) were weighed under nitrogen into a 25 mL Erlenmeyer flask having silanized glass walls. The reaction vessel was closed with glass-stopper and steel spring and immersed into an oil bath preheated to 120 °C. After 0.5 h at 120 °C and cooling the polylactone was dissolved in dichloromethane and precipitated into cold diethyl ether.

(B) With Ultradry ε-Caprolactone (No. 8, II, Table )

Ultradry ε-caprolactone (100 mmol) and Ph2BiOEt (0.1 mmol) were weighed under pure argon into a 50 mL Erlenmeyer flask having silanized glass walls. Polymerization and workup procedure were the same as described above.

elements.content: The inherent viscosities were measured in CH2Cl2 with an automated Ubbelohde viscometer thermostated at 20 °C. The size exclusion chromatography (SEC) measurements were conducted with an apparatus of Polymer Laboratories equipped with a RI-detector “Shodex RI detector”. Three identical PC mixed-bed columns (PL mixed C, 5 μ) were used and chloroform served as eluent at a flow rate of 1 mL/min. Commercial polystyrene standards served for calibration. The 400 MHz 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance 400 FT spectrometer in 5 mm o.d. sample tubes. CHCl3 containing tetramethyl silane served as solvent. The MALDI−TOF mass spectra were measured with a Bruker Biflex III mass spectrometer equipped with a nitrogen laser (λ = 337 nm). All spectra were recorded in the reflection mode with an acceleration voltage of 20 kV. The irradiation targets were prepared from chloroform solutions (1 mL) with the following quantities: polylactone, 10 mg (or less); dithranol, 25 mg; and potassium trifluoroacetate, 3 mg.
elements.clean_text:
Measurements

The inherent viscosities were measured in CH2Cl2 with an automated Ubbelohde viscometer thermostated at 20 °C. The size exclusion chromatography (SEC) measurements were conducted with an apparatus of Polymer Laboratories equipped with a RI-detector "Shodex RI detector". Three identical PC mixed-bed columns (PL mixed C, 5 μ) were used and chloroform served as eluent at a flow rate of 1 mL/min. Commercial polystyrene standards served for calibration. The 400 MHz 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance 400 FT spectrometer in 5 mm o.d. sample tubes. CHCl3 containing tetramethyl silane served as solvent. The MALDI-TOF mass spectra were measured with a Bruker Biflex III mass spectrometer equipped with a nitrogen laser (λ = 337 nm). All spectra were recorded in the reflection mode with an acceleration voltage of 20 kV. The irradiation targets were prepared from chloroform solutions (1 mL) with the following quantities: polylactone, 10 mg (or less); dithranol, 25 mg; and potassium trifluoroacetate, 3 mg.

elements.content:
CCDC-654355 contains the supporting crystallographic data. This data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

Results and DiscussionReactivity Studies

In addition to the preparative aspects it was of great interest to elucidate, how the reactivity of Ph2BiOEt correlates with the reactivities of other established initiators. For this purpose, polymerizations of εCL were conducted in bulk at 120 °C (Ph2BiOEt decomposes at higher temperatures) and the conversions were determined from time-to-time by means of 1H NMR spectroscopy. For this evaluation the CO-CH2 signal of εCL at 2.6 ppm and the CO-CH2 signal of poly(εCL) at 2.3 ppm were used. Since Bi(III) n-hexanoate in equimolar combination with an alcohol was preferentially used in previous studies of Bi-initiated ROPs, BiHex3 + ethanol served as second standard. The time conversion curves obtained from these three initiators are displayed in Figure . As expected Ph2BiOEt is more reactive than BiHex3 + ethanol (by a factor of 2:1 at 50% conversion).
elements.clean_text:
CCDC-654355 contains the supporting crystallographic data. This data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

Results and Discussion

Reactivity Studies

In addition to the preparative aspects it was of great interest to elucidate, how the reactivity of Ph2BiOEt correlates with the reactivities of other established initiators. For this purpose, polymerizations of εCL were conducted in bulk at 120 °C (Ph2BiOEt decomposes at higher temperatures) and the conversions were determined from time-to-time by means of 1H NMR spectroscopy. For this evaluation the CO-CH2 signal of εCL at 2.6 ppm and the CO-CH2 signal of poly(εCL) at 2.3 ppm were used. Since Bi(III) n-hexanoate in equimolar combination with an alcohol was preferentially used in previous studies of Bi-initiated ROPs, BiHex3 + ethanol served as second standard. The time conversion curves obtained from these three initiators are displayed in Figure . As expected Ph2BiOEt is more reactive than BiHex3 + ethanol (by a factor of 2:1 at 50% conversion).

elements.content: Time−conversion curves obtained from polymerizations of εCL in bulk at 120 °C with (A) SnOct2 + ethanol as initiator, (B) with Ph2BiOEt, and (C) with BiHex3 + ethanol (M/I = 200 in all three cases).
elements.clean_text: 1  Time-conversion curves obtained from polymerizations of εCL in bulk at 120 °C with (A) SnOct2 + ethanol as initiator, (B) with Ph2BiOEt, and (C) with BiHex3 + ethanol (M/I = 200 in all three cases).

elements.content: This expectation was based on the following facts. First, it is well-known from several metals that their alkoxides are more reactive as initiators than their carboxylates or halides. Detailed studies of reactivities and reaction mechanisms were recently published for various tin(III) and tin(IV) alkoxides and carboxylates. The coordination insertion mechanism outlined for Ph2BiOEt in was confirmed for all tin alkoxides. In the case of carboxylates, addition of an alcohol accelerated the polymerization and yields ester endgroups. These observations and model reactions confirmed that a (partial) exchange of carboxylate against alkoxide groups precedes the propagation step as formulated for BiHex3 in . All experimental observations made for Bi-salt-initiated polymerizations agree with these reaction mechanisms, and the MALDI−TOF mass spectra discussed below provide additional evidence. Figure also demonstrates that Ph2BiOEt is less reactive than SnOct2 + ethanol (by a factor of 7 at 50% conversion). The observation that BiHex3 + alcohol is a less reactive initiator system than SnOct2 + alcohol was already reported in previous publications. The results presented in Figure suggest at first glance that Ph2BiOEt brings little progress in direction of a higher reactivity.
elements.clean_text: This expectation was based on the following facts. First, it is well-known from several metals that their alkoxides are more reactive as initiators than their carboxylates or halides. Detailed studies of reactivities and reaction mechanisms were recently published for various tin(III) and tin(IV) alkoxides and carboxylates. The coordination insertion mechanism outlined for Ph2BiOEt in  was confirmed for all tin alkoxides. In the case of carboxylates, addition of an alcohol accelerated the polymerization and yields ester endgroups. These observations and model reactions confirmed that a (partial) exchange of carboxylate against alkoxide groups precedes the propagation step as formulated for BiHex3 in . All experimental observations made for Bi-salt-initiated polymerizations agree with these reaction mechanisms, and the MALDI-TOF mass spectra discussed below provide additional evidence. Figure  also demonstrates that Ph2BiOEt is less reactive than SnOct2 + ethanol (by a factor of 7 at 50% conversion). The observation that BiHex3 + alcohol is a less reactive initiator system than SnOct2 + alcohol was already reported in previous publications. The results presented in Figure  suggest at first glance that Ph2BiOEt brings little progress in direction of a higher reactivity.

elements.content: The reactivity of Ph2BiOEt was further studied by reducing the M/I ratio to 50/1 to accelerate the conversion, and the temperature was lowered in steps of 20 °C. The conversion was complete in a few hours even at 60 °C. Surprisingly, a nearly complete polymerization was also achieved at 40 °C, although partial crystallization of poly(εCL) affected the course of this polymerization. These results prompted us to compare the reactivity of Ph2BiOEt with those of BiHex3 + ethanol and SnOct2 + ethanol at 90 and 60 °C. As illustrated by Figure , the Ph2BiOEt-initiated polymerization is as rapid as the SnOct2 + ethanol-initiated one and faster at higher conversions, when compared at 90 °C. At 60 °C the difference in the reactivities of SnOct2 + ethanol and BiHex3 + ethanol did again not significantly change. Yet, Ph2BiOEt proved to be approximately 25 times more efficient as initiator than SnOct2 + ethanol (Figure ). This result demonstrates for the first time that a bismuth-based initiator may be more reactive than the combination of SnOct2 with a primary alcohol. To the best of our knowledge a similar comparison of a metal alkoxide with SnOct2 and ethanol was not published yet, and we cannot forward a satisfactory explanation of the experimental data at this time.
elements.clean_text: The reactivity of Ph2BiOEt was further studied by reducing the M/I ratio to 50/1 to accelerate the conversion, and the temperature was lowered in steps of 20 °C. The conversion was complete in a few hours even at 60 °C. Surprisingly, a nearly complete polymerization was also achieved at 40 °C, although partial crystallization of poly(εCL) affected the course of this polymerization. These results prompted us to compare the reactivity of Ph2BiOEt with those of BiHex3 + ethanol and SnOct2 + ethanol at 90 and 60 °C. As illustrated by Figure , the Ph2BiOEt-initiated polymerization is as rapid as the SnOct2 + ethanol-initiated one and faster at higher conversions, when compared at 90 °C. At 60 °C the difference in the reactivities of SnOct2 + ethanol and BiHex3 + ethanol did again not significantly change. Yet, Ph2BiOEt proved to be approximately 25 times more efficient as initiator than SnOct2 + ethanol (Figure ). This result demonstrates for the first time that a bismuth-based initiator may be more reactive than the combination of SnOct2 with a primary alcohol. To the best of our knowledge a similar comparison of a metal alkoxide with SnOct2 and ethanol was not published yet, and we cannot forward a satisfactory explanation of the experimental data at this time.

elements.content: Time−conversion curves obtained from polymerizations of εCL in bulk at 90 °C with (A) SnOct2 + ethanol, (B) with Ph2BiOEt, and (C) with BiHex3 + ethanol (M/I = 50 in all three cases).
elements.clean_text: 2  Time-conversion curves obtained from polymerizations of εCL in bulk at 90 °C with (A) SnOct2 + ethanol, (B) with Ph2BiOEt, and (C) with BiHex3 + ethanol (M/I = 50 in all three cases).

elements.content: Time−conversion curves obtained from polymerizations of εCL in bulk at 60 °C with (A) SnOct2 + ethanol, (B) with Ph2BiOEt, and (C) with Ph2BiOEt and BiHex3 + ethanol (M/I = 50/1 in all three cases).
elements.clean_text: 3  Time-conversion curves obtained from polymerizations of εCL in bulk at 60 °C with (A) SnOct2 + ethanol, (B) with Ph2BiOEt, and (C) with Ph2BiOEt and BiHex3 + ethanol (M/I = 50/1 in all three cases).

elements.content: Finally, three Ph2BiOEt-initiated polymerizations were performed at 20 °C. These polymerizations were conducted in concentrated solutions to avoid problems with rapidly crystallizing oligo(εCL)s and to find out, if the nature of the solvent has a significant influence on the rate of polymerization. The results presented in Figure demonstrate that Ph2BiOEt initiates the ROP of εCL even at 20 °C, but the solvent plays a key role for the success of the polymerization. The polymerization should be particularly slow in THF, because this solvent can better coordinate with the Bi atom than toluene or dichloromethane, and the coordination with Bi should hinder the access of εCL. However, the opposite trend was found. In this connection, the time conversion curves of Ph2BiOEt presented in Figures show a sigmoidal shape. This means that in the beginning of the polymerization an activation process takes place. This observation and the positive influence of THF may speculatively be interpreted by assuming an association between two (or more) Ph2BiOEt molecules which is broken up by THF or εCL and its growing chain thereby activating the initiator. This hypothesis is supported by the following observations. First, the hitherto unknown crystal structure was determined, and its schematic illustration in Figure demonstrates that the O-atom forms a bridge between two Bi atoms. Second, it is well documented in numerous publications that tin alkoxides associate via donor–acceptor interactions.
elements.clean_text: Finally, three Ph2BiOEt-initiated polymerizations were performed at 20 °C. These polymerizations were conducted in concentrated solutions to avoid problems with rapidly crystallizing oligo(εCL)s and to find out, if the nature of the solvent has a significant influence on the rate of polymerization. The results presented in Figure  demonstrate that Ph2BiOEt initiates the ROP of εCL even at 20 °C, but the solvent plays a key role for the success of the polymerization. The polymerization should be particularly slow in THF, because this solvent can better coordinate with the Bi atom than toluene or dichloromethane, and the coordination with Bi should hinder the access of εCL. However, the opposite trend was found. In this connection, the time conversion curves of Ph2BiOEt presented in Figures    show a sigmoidal shape. This means that in the beginning of the polymerization an activation process takes place. This observation and the positive influence of THF may speculatively be interpreted by assuming an association between two (or more) Ph2BiOEt molecules which is broken up by THF or εCL and its growing chain thereby activating the initiator. This hypothesis is supported by the following observations. First, the hitherto unknown crystal structure was determined, and its schematic illustration in Figure  demonstrates that the O-atom forms a bridge between two Bi atoms. Second, it is well documented in numerous publications that tin alkoxides associate via donor-acceptor interactions.

elements.content: Finally, the MALDI−TOF mass spectra should be discussed. Regardless of the polymerization temperature the mass spectra display the same pattern exemplarily illustrated in Figure . The only class of linear chains are polylactones having ethyl ester and one CH2OH endgroup in perfect agreement with the coordination-insertion mechanism outlined in Scheme . Furthermore, a small percentage of cyclic oligoesters was found. The oligomers (regardless if cyclic or not) are not detectable as a separate maximum in the SEC elution curves and represent a weight fraction ≤1%. The formation of cyclic oligoesters by back-biting was observed for metal-alkoxide initiated polymerizations of lactones (and lactide) at temperatures ≥100 °C. Yet, surprising is the finding that cyclic oligolactones were found in this study even at a reaction temperature as low as 20 °C, although only traces of cycles were detectable at this temperature.
elements.clean_text: Finally, the MALDI-TOF mass spectra should be discussed. Regardless of the polymerization temperature the mass spectra display the same pattern exemplarily illustrated in Figure . The only class of linear chains are polylactones having ethyl ester and one CH2OH endgroup in perfect agreement with the coordination-insertion mechanism outlined in Scheme . Furthermore, a small percentage of cyclic oligoesters was found. The oligomers (regardless if cyclic or not) are not detectable as a separate maximum in the SEC elution curves and represent a weight fraction ≤1%. The formation of cyclic oligoesters by back-biting was observed for metal-alkoxide initiated polymerizations of lactones (and lactide) at temperatures ≥100 °C. Yet, surprising is the finding that cyclic oligolactones were found in this study even at a reaction temperature as low as 20 °C, although only traces of cycles were detectable at this temperature.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic id="gs1" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ma-2007-01797i_0006.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

The influence of the M/I ratio on Mn was studied by two series of polymerizations conducted at 120 °C in bulk. This relatively high temperature was selected, because the conversion per time decreases with higher M/I ratios. At first, εCL distilled over powdered calcium hydride served as monomer and the experiments nos. 1–5 and 6A, 7A, and 8A in Table were performed with εCL of this quality (dry εCL). The inherent viscosities increased with higher M/I ratios, but the measured M ns (corrected values) deviated from the calculated M ns at M/I ratios above 300/1 with a tendency toward lower molar masses. The calculated values were obtained by multiplication of the M/I ratio with a conversion of 98% (as indicated by 1H NMR spectroscopy). The corrected M n values resulted from multiplication of the experimental data obtained by calibration with polystyrene with the factor 0.68. This factor (±0.02) came into play for the following reasons. First, Schindler et al. reported a Mark–Houwink−Sakurada equation (eq 5), which as demonstrated previously suggests such a correction factor for Mn values above 10 000 Da. Second, 1H NMR endgroup analyses of copolyesters of εCL confirmed this factor. Third, several research groups have demonstrated by means of various analytical methods that the direct calibration with polystyrene overestimates the real molar masses of poly(εCL) and other aliphatic polyesters by 50–80%. The relatively low yields listed in Table resulted from incomplete precipitation into diethyl ether.
elements.clean_text:
Preparative Aspects

The influence of the M/I ratio on Mn was studied by two series of polymerizations conducted at 120 °C in bulk. This relatively high temperature was selected, because the conversion per time decreases with higher M/I ratios. At first, εCL distilled over powdered calcium hydride served as monomer and the experiments nos. 1-5 and 6A, 7A, and 8A in Table  were performed with εCL of this quality (dry εCL). The inherent viscosities increased with higher M/I ratios, but the measured M ns (corrected values) deviated from the calculated M ns at M/I ratios above 300/1 with a tendency toward lower molar masses. The calculated values were obtained by multiplication of the M/I ratio with a conversion of 98% (as indicated by 1H NMR spectroscopy). The corrected M n values resulted from multiplication of the experimental data obtained by calibration with polystyrene with the factor 0.68. This factor (±0.02) came into play for the following reasons. First, Schindler et al. reported a Mark-Houwink-Sakurada equation (eq 5), which as demonstrated previously suggests such a correction factor for Mn values above 10000 Da. Second, 1H NMR endgroup analyses of copolyesters of εCL confirmed this factor. Third, several research groups have demonstrated by means of various analytical methods that the direct calibration with polystyrene overestimates the real molar masses of poly(εCL) and other aliphatic polyesters by 50-80%. The relatively low yields listed in Table  resulted from incomplete precipitation into diethyl ether.

elements.content: From previous polymerizations of εCL, it was learned that this monomer when distilled once or twice over calcium hydride may still contain traces of water. To find out if these traces of water are responsible for the lower M n values obtained with M/I ratios ≥400, four more polymerizations were conducted with a so-called ultradry εCL. This εCL was first distilled over CaH2 and immediately afterward over P4O10 (with a loss of 45–50%). Furthermore, these polymerizations were performed under an atmosphere of dry argon (footnotes and in Table ). Under these optimized conditions, M n values were obtained which were in satisfactory agreement with the calculated ones. These results prove that the Ph2BiOEt-initiated polymerizations allow a control of the molar masses via the M/I ratio at least up to 115 000 Da. Another useful piece of information concerns the polydispersities which increase with longer reaction times.
elements.clean_text: From previous polymerizations of εCL, it was learned that this monomer when distilled once or twice over calcium hydride may still contain traces of water. To find out if these traces of water are responsible for the lower M n values obtained with M/I ratios ≥400, four more polymerizations were conducted with a so-called ultradry εCL. This εCL was first distilled over CaH2 and immediately afterward over P4O10 (with a loss of 45-50%). Furthermore, these polymerizations were performed under an atmosphere of dry argon (footnotes  and  in Table ). Under these optimized conditions, M n values were obtained which were in satisfactory agreement with the calculated ones. These results prove that the Ph2BiOEt-initiated polymerizations allow a control of the molar masses via the M/I ratio at least up to 115000 Da. Another useful piece of information concerns the polydispersities which increase with longer reaction times.

elements.content: In our first studies of bicatalyzed polymerizations of εCL or l-lactide Bi(III)acetate or n-hexanoate were used in combination with diols, triols, or tetraols to prepare telechelic and star-shaped polymers. In these experiments M ns up to 23 000 Da were realized, but no attempt was made to test the upper limit of the polymerization process. With the results of Ph2BiOEt in hand four more experiments were performed in this work using Bi(III)acetate in a 1:1 combination with ethanol as initiator. For comparison with Ph2BiOEt, the M/I ratio was fixed at 1000/1, the temperature at 120 °C (nos. 1 + 2, Table ) and ultradry εCL was used. Because of the lower reactivity of Bi(III)acetate two more polymerizations were conducted at 150 °C (nos. 3 + 4, Table ). Regardless of the reaction conditions, viscosity and SEC measurements proved that the highest Mn values did not exceed 50% of the best result obtained from Ph2BiOEt. Together with the rather low reactivity of BiHex3 illustrated in Figures , these results indicate that the simple Bi(III)carboxylates are not suited to prepare high molecular weights poly εCL (but they have the advantage of an extraordinarily low toxicity).
elements.clean_text: In our first studies of bicatalyzed polymerizations of εCL or l-lactide Bi(III)acetate or n-hexanoate were used in combination with diols, triols, or tetraols to prepare telechelic and star-shaped polymers. In these experiments M ns up to 23000 Da were realized, but no attempt was made to test the upper limit of the polymerization process. With the results of Ph2BiOEt in hand four more experiments were performed in this work using Bi(III)acetate in a 1:1 combination with ethanol as initiator. For comparison with Ph2BiOEt, the M/I ratio was fixed at 1000/1, the temperature at 120 °C (nos. 1 + 2, Table ) and ultradry εCL was used. Because of the lower reactivity of Bi(III)acetate two more polymerizations were conducted at 150 °C (nos. 3 + 4, Table ). Regardless of the reaction conditions, viscosity and SEC measurements proved that the highest Mn values did not exceed 50% of the best result obtained from Ph2BiOEt. Together with the rather low reactivity of BiHex3 illustrated in Figures   , these results indicate that the simple Bi(III)carboxylates are not suited to prepare high molecular weights poly εCL (but they have the advantage of an extraordinarily low toxicity).

Bi(OAc)<sub>3</sub>-Initiated,<xref rid="tbl2-fn1"></xref> TEG-Coinitiated<xref rid="tbl2-fn2"></xref> Polymerizations of εCL in Bulk expt no. temp (°C) time (h) yield (%) ηinh (dL/g) M n (corr) polydispersity 1 120 13 87.0 1.15 48000 2.2 2 120 40 87.5 0.96 42000 2.2 3 150 3 86.0 0.88 35000 2.1 4 150 7 86.5 0.85 33000 2.1

εCL/Bi(OAc)3 feed ratio: 1000/1.

Determined after precipitation into diethyl ether.

Inherent viscosity measured at 20 °C with c = 2 g/L in CH2Cl2.

Size-exclusion chromatography measurements calibrated with polystyrene and multiplied with the correction factor 0.68.

Diphenylbismuth ethoxide was the first single-site bismuth initiator used for the ring-opening polymerization of a lactone. As expected, it proved to be considerably more reactive than bismuth(III) n-hexanoate and enabled polymerizations of εCL even at 40 °C. At temperatures ≤90 °C it was more reactive than the SnOct2/ethanol initiator combination. Furthermore, it allowed for a control of the molecular weight of poly(εCL) via the M/I ratio up to molecular weights above 105 Da. These results indicate that bisaryl bismuth alkoxides are an interesting class of initiators for lactones (and possibly for other cyclic esters) and certainly deserve further studies.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Diphenylbismuth ethoxide was the first single-site bismuth initiator used for the ring-opening polymerization of a lactone. As expected, it proved to be considerably more reactive than bismuth(III) n-hexanoate and enabled polymerizations of εCL even at 40 °C. At temperatures ≤90 °C it was more reactive than the SnOct2/ethanol initiator combination. Furthermore, it allowed for a control of the molecular weight of poly(εCL) via the M/I ratio up to molecular weights above 105 Da. These results indicate that bisaryl bismuth alkoxides are an interesting class of initiators for lactones (and possibly for other cyclic esters) and certainly deserve further studies.

cln_elements.content: ε-Caprolactone (50 mmol) and Ph2BiOEt (0.5 mmol) were weighed under nitrogen into a 25 mL Erlenmeyer flask having silanized glass walls. The reaction vessel was closed with glass-stopper and steel spring and immersed into an oil bath preheated to 120 °C. After 0.5 h at 120 °C and cooling the polylactone was dissolved in dichloromethane and precipitated into cold diethyl ether.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Polymerizations

(A) With Dry ε-Caprolactone (No. 2, Table ).

ε-Caprolactone (50 mmol) and Ph2BiOEt (0.5 mmol) were weighed under nitrogen into a 25 mL Erlenmeyer flask having silanized glass walls. The reaction vessel was closed with glass-stopper and steel spring and immersed into an oil bath preheated to 120 °C. After 0.5 h at 120 °C and cooling the polylactone was dissolved in dichloromethane and precipitated into cold diethyl ether.
